docs.lead_paragraph: PARKINSON'S By WALTER SULLIVAN SURGEONS in Stockholm plan soon to insert, in the brain of a patient suffering from Parkinson's disease, cells taken from that person's adrenal glands. Their hope is that this, the first known attempt to transplant tissue into a human brain, will counter the tremors and other symptoms of that disease. If successful, the method might be applicable to some other brain disorders, such as Huntington's chorea and damage due to strokes. Although the planned treatment for Parkinsonism is untested in humans, the procedure is the fruit of eight years of research and animal experiments by the Stockholm group and its collaborators at the National Institute of Mental Health in Washington, D.C., and at the University of Colorado Health Sciences Center in Denver. The Americans are not participating in the experiment on a human patient. The animal tests have shown the brain to be what the experimenters call a ''privileged site'' for transplants. This is because the brain typically does not reject transplants, unlike other parts of the body, where immune defenders destroy such intrusions.

headline.main: NEW TISSUE WILL BE IMPLANTED IN BRAIN TO TREAT

docs.lead_paragraph: Vital functions of the Federal Government, including national security, public health, borrowing, tax collection and air traffic control, were set to continue Monday regardless of the outcome of the Congressional efforts to pass a stopgap spending measure that would keep money flowing for Government services. A Government contingency plan allows for staffing and operating those functions on a deferred-payment basis. Technically, the Federal Government moved into a state of ''appropriations hiatus'' at 12:01 A.M. Saturday, meaning that no money was being authorized for continuing Government functions. But the major effect was not to be felt until Monday, the first weekday after the last funding bill expired.

headline.main: PLAN PERMITS MANY AGENCIES TO RUN WITHOUT NEW FUNDS
